subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-819404861-1241999734=:81472
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Who to go to?=A0 The scientific method!

This was a good example of how a c=
ouple people, with differing opinions but open minds, can follow an objecti=
ve methodology to root out the right answer.

1) Observation.=A0 We heard (=
indirectly) that someone has seen wave files experience lossy compression w=
hen sent through email clients.

2) Hypothesis.=A0 The theory is that the e=
mail client, and/or email servers, perform lossy compression on their attac=
hments for wave files.

3) Predictions.=A0 Based on this hypothesis, this s=
hould be observable by attaching and sending large waves files through some=
 email servers, and comparing both the originals, and the final files.=A0 I=
f original files and the final files should experience differences in conte=
nts.

4) Experiments.=A0 We sent different files, of different sizes, throu=
gh different clients and servers.=A0 

5) Analyze results.=A0 We compared t=
he originals at the byte level, and found no loss.

6) Interpret.=A0 No com=
pression was observed in our tests, and so no compression is being done wit=
h the servers and clients and environments in which we tested.=A0 This does=
 not make any claims about other tests or environments, but provides good t=
esting and predictions for what would be expected based on our tests.

With=
out this kind of method, we could have just gone back and forth giving subj=
ective or emotional arguments, with no real evidence.=A0 But following this=
 kind of method, we get to what we really both wanted: reliable interpretat=
ion of phenomenon.

And this doesn't mean we need to close the books foreve=
r.=A0 More prediction, more experiments, more results can be tried by more =
people, published, and reproduced.=A0 The body of knowledge then grows wide=
r, deeper, and more reliable.

This is why I push the scientific method eve=
n with EVP studies, even while others continue subjective or emotional argu=
ments: to improve the study, and to allow progress to be made by as many pe=
ople as possible.

      Yep, that's exactly what that =
comparison does.=A0 It 
        compares each and every byte (all their 
bi=
ts) from file to 
        file.=A0 If the same bytes are in both files, in =
the same places, 
        they are the same.=A0 One tiny little difference,=
 and it tells 
        you.

        =
        If the audio had been resampled, you could 
                  expec=
t less bytes, or different bytes, but not the same number 
                =
  of the same bytes.=A0 That's why comparing the bytes in 
                =
  both files can rule that out, if no changes are 
                  found.=

 if the

n

       =

t fully trust 
                    the bit comparison because I don't trust=
 that the bytes

tion, such as we 
                    discussed earlier. But that is largel=
y because I have no 
                    clue at that level of things what =
is actually going 
                    on.

Design experience and working with photo

nly have that=A0knowledge to use to compare.

       =
               
                      
                      
             =
           
                        
                          They are not=
 necessarily the same 
                            bytes, but I was proposi=
ng a quick check just to see 
                            if the files were=
 in the same ballpark.=A0 Look 
                            at it the other=
 way: if the number of bytes were 
                            DIFFERENT, t=
han you'd know the files HAD changed, 
                            and you =
could stop testing.=A0 But if the number 
                            of by=
tes are the same, it tends to indicate the 
                            fil=
es are likely the same, but you still need a low 
                         =
   level file comparison to be sure.

My method 
                          =
  is to compare the files using the CMP command in 
                       =
     unix.=A0 There are many programs to compare 
                         =
   files, but you have to be careful not to use one 
                      =
      that does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison 
                  =
          meant for text files), since text files can be 
                 =
           different at a low level, but look essential the 
              =
              same in an editor (because of the way spaces and 
           =
                 tabs and new lines work between editors and 
             =
               platforms).

But anyway, the way to compare is 
            =
                with a program that can compare binary files, not 
        =
                    text files.

                              So=
 if the 
                              number of bytes match then they are =
the same 
                              bytes? See where my confusion comes=
 
                              in?
                              =A0
     =
                         How does one 
                              do a b=
it-level comparison? Is there a program that 
                             =
 does that, or is there some way of comparison by 
                        =
      looking at the file's properties?
                              =A0
 =
                             ----- 
                                Origina=
l Message ----- 
                                From: 
                   =
             Rj

ay 10, 2009 3:35 PM

          =
                      JON
                                

               =
                 
                                
                        =
        
                                
                                
=
                                A file's content, it's integrity, 
        =
                        is simply the bytes (and their bits) in the 
      =
                          file.=A0 If the file's content integrity is 
    =
                            changed, that is, by definition, changing the 
=
                                bytes.=A0 If the bytes in there are not 
  =
                              changed, then that integrity has not 
       =
                         changed.

It is possible to mess with 
           =
                     other things about a file (like its name, its 
       =
                         suffix, or its ownership) but this does not 
     =
                           effect the contents, and so would not affect 
  =
                              that integrity, or the sound of the file 
   =
                             (assuming you could read it at all after 
    =
                            changing the ownership, or the suffix, 
       =
                         etc).

When you do your tests, if you 
           =
                     cannot do a bit level comparison, I would 
           =
                     recommend at least checking the file 
                =
                sizes.=A0 If they are identical, there is a 
              =
                  very high probability that the content has not 
         =
                       changed.

                              =
  
                                
                                
      =
                          
                                Yes you can tell=
 loss of quality 
                                by a bit-level comparison=
.=A0 An audio file 
                                is just a file of bytes=
, that is later 
                                interpreted by an audio pl=
ayer.=A0 Two files 
                                with the exact same con=
tents, whether they are 
                                audio or image or =
a dababase or an exe, are 
                                indistinguishabl=
e from each other.=A0 That 
                                is, if I copied=
 the contents of one to a new 
                                file, and th=
e contents of the other to a new 
                                file, and=
 asked you which file each came from, 
                                ther=
e would be no way to tell.=A0 Even the 
                                aud=
io player could not tell.=A0 The data is 
                                i=
dentical, and so the sound (or the picture, 
                              =
  etc) would be identical.

Yes I did listen 
                             =
   to the results, but that is not the best test 
                         =
       (they sounded identical, but that is a 
                            =
    subjective opinion).=A0 The real test is 
                             =
   compring the contents.=A0 Identical contents 
                          =
      means indentical data, means identical 
                             =
   audio.

It is probably possible to set up 
                             =
   an email compression scheme that does do lossy 
                        =
        audio compression.=A0 My tests show my setup 
                     =
           does not.=A0 If you'd like me to help test 
                    =
            your setup, we can do that too. From what I see, 
             =
                   lossy compression from an attachment would be 
         =
                       very unusual.

                  =
              
                                
                           =
     
                                For 
                                =
executables, you may be right. However, for wav 
                          =
      files, the compression during email is not loss 
                    =
            less. 
                                =A0
                    =
            I used to 
                                think as you do, in =
that the emailed 
                                attachment=A0of a wav fil=
e would not loose 
                                anything. After a length=
y discourse with another 
                                member here, I le=
arned that I was wrong. The 
                                reason why=A0I=
 did not realize it in the 
                                first place is =
that when I would email a wav 
                                file, I woul=
d intentionally keep it in very 
                                small segm=
ents, to keep file size down. This was 
                                jus=
t for ease of transfer. But because of this, 
                             =
   I had not experienced any noticeable 
                                lo=
ss.
                                =A0
                                Now=
 it may 
                                be in some cases, depending on the=
 servers or 
                                what have you that the file go=
es through, that 
                                the loss may be less or m=
ore. But once the 
                                attachment is 
         =
                       downloaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been 
            =
                    found to be less then the original 
                   =
             wav.
                                =A0
                     =
           Again though 
                                you can only reall=
y tell when the=A0wav file 
                                is large.
     =
                           =A0
                                ----- Origin=
al Message ----- 
                                
                        =
        From: 
                                Rj 
                        =
        
                                To: 
                             =
   EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: 
       =
                         Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                     =
           Subject: 
                                Re: [EVP-ITC] File upl=
oading rules
                                

                            =
    
                                
                                
    =
                            
                                
             =
                   The kind of compression that 
                          =
      occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
                   =
             it compress the file cleverly without losing 
                =
                information.=A0 For example, if I had a 
                  =
              program in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
             =
                   email, it could compress it.=A0 But if it 
             =
                   lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
       =
                         not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
  =
                              the other side.

This kind of compression 
  =
                              does things like looking for common patterns =
in 
                                the file, and replacing them with a tok=
en.=A0 
                                A rough example would be if it foun=
d "Howdy 
                                Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it =
could replace 
                                all the occurances with say =
$HN1.=A0 And also 
                                write a little dictionar=
y in there someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHow=
dy Neighbor".

When the 
                                file gets to its d=
estination it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all=
 occurences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "How=
dy Neighbor".=A0 So it was 
                                compressed (ins=
tead of 14 characters each, it 
                                only needed=
 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                                data=
.

Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                are no=
t lossless.=A0 Depending on the level 
                                of c=
ompression, some level of data is lost, and 
                              =
  so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                                =
later.

Rick

                          =
      
                                
                                
  =
                              Another 
                                thin=
g:
                                =A0
                                I re=
cently 
                                found this out. When you email a fi=
le, if it is 
                                not saved as a compressed for=
mat, the email 
                                filtering process will actu=
ally compress the 
                                file automatically.
    =
                            =A0
                                So even if =

                                you have attached a wav. file, it will loo=
se 
                                resolution over the email process. It w=
ill not 
                                sound exactly the same as the orig=
inal wav. 
                                file. How much it differs depend=
s on the size of 
                                the file you are attachin=
g. If it is a 
                                very=A0large file, it will s=
ound much 
                                different.
                     =
           =A0
                                The only 
                  =
              exception to this is if the wav. file is small 
             =
                   enough that the filtering process will ignore 
         =
                       it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 
  =
                              1=A0MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
       =
                         threshold).
                                =A0
  =
                              The best way 
                               =
 to share files over the internet=A0if you 
                               =
 want them as close to the original as possible 
                          =
      is to upload them directly to a 
                                webs=
ite.
                                =A0
                                
 =

                                Origi=
nal Message ----- 
                                From: 
                 =
               Rj

                      Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                  =
              

                                
                          =
      
                                
                                
  =
                              
                                
Pixelizatio=
n doesn't clean-up 
                                the data: it replaces i=
t.=A0 Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a field =
of flowers, and beginning to 
                                add levels or=
 pixelization to the picture.=A0 
                                Soon, you=
 would not be able to tell there were 
                                flow=
ers there at all.=A0 You would see a lot 
                                o=
f colored blocks.

Or in the other 
                                directi=
on, imagine you are looking at a 
                                competely=
 randomize bunch of pixes on your 
                                screen: =
a complete screen of truely random 
                                static =
snow.=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
                                while, y=
ou would again start to see colored 
                                blocks=
.

What's happening is that it is 
                                processi=
ng an area of the image, taking (for 
                                insta=
nce) the average value of that entire area, 
                              =
  and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                         =
       the average.=A0 In video processing, this 
                         =
       would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                  =
              being replaced by, for instance, a big 
                     =
           greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                  =
              flowers.=A0 In the noise example, it maybe 
                 =
               replace all the random pixels with another big 
            =
                    greyish-bluish block.=A0 If you did not know 
         =
                       beforehand what the original picture was, you 
     =
                           couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
=
                                really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky=
 with 
                                clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.=


It 
                                works the same with the sound files.=
=A0 
                                Taking something as complex as speech,=
 and 
                                replacing frequencies with their aver=
ages, loses 
                                the speech the farther you go,=
 until you head 
                                strange fluctuating square=
 waves.=A0 Doing 
                                the same to random static=
 will eventually 
                                produce the same thing.=
=A0 And random 
                                fluctuating square waves ca=
n sound a bit like 
                                speech - or at least, y=
ou could have fun sharing 
                                with each other =
what you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.

          =
                      Be a bit careful of formats like 
                   =
             mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
             =
                   sounds though.=A0=A0 While some formats 
               =
                 (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
        =
                        way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
   =
                             the file, and in so doing lose some of the son=
ic 
                                details.=A0 This may not be a big deal =
in 
                                music, where the audio is fairly clear =
to begin 
                                with.=A0 But with sound sources w=
ith a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this can n=
ot only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixel=
ize non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make=
 them start to sound like 
                                speech.

So mp3 =
might be good for sharing 
                                the data, once y=
ou've already formed an opinion 
                                based on a=
n analysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
                                mp3 is =
not good as a medium for analysis.=A0 
                                It c=
an lead to many false positives and 
                                misint=
erpretations.

<table cellspacing=3D"0" cellpadding=3D"0" border=3D"0" ><tr><td valign=3D"=
top" style=3D"font: inherit;">Who to go to?  The scientific method!<br=
><br>This was a good example of how a couple people, with differing opinion=
s but open minds, can follow an objective methodology to root out the right=
 answer.<br><br>1) Observation.  We heard (indirectly) that someone ha=
s seen wave files experience lossy compression when sent through email clie=
nts.<br><br>2) Hypothesis.  The theory is that the email client, and/o=
r email servers, perform lossy compression on their attachments for wave fi=
les.<br><br>3) Predictions.  Based on this hypothesis, this should be =
observable by attaching and sending large waves files through some email se=
rvers, and comparing both the originals, and the final files.  If orig=
inal files and the final files should experience differences in contents.<b=
r><br>4) Experiments.  We sent different files, of different sizes,
 t=
hrough different clients and servers.  <br><br>5) Analyze results.&nbs=
p; We compared the originals at the byte level, and found no loss.<br><br>6=
) Interpret.  No compression was observed in our tests, and so no comp=
ression is being done with the servers and clients and environments in whic=
h we tested.  This does not make any claims about other tests or envir=
onments, but provides good testing and predictions for what would be expect=
ed based on our tests.<br><br>Without this kind of method, we could have ju=
st gone back and forth giving subjective or emotional arguments, with no re=
al evidence.  But following this kind of method, we get to what we rea=
lly both wanted: reliable interpretation of phenomenon.<br><br>And this doe=
sn't mean we need to close the books forever.  More prediction, more e=
xperiments, more results can be tried by more people, published, and reprod=
uced.  The body of knowledge then grows wider, deeper, and
 more relia=
ble.<br><br>This is why I push the scientific method even with EVP studies,=
 even while others continue subjective or emotional arguments: to improve t=
he study, and to allow progress to be made by as many people as possible.<b=
r><br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <i><apri=

                    <td valign=3D"top">They are not necessarily the same 
 =
                           bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to=
 see 
                            if the files were in the same ballpark.&n=
bsp; Look 
                            at it the other way: if the number o=
f bytes were 
                            DIFFERENT, than you'd know the fi=
les HAD changed, 
                            and you could stop testing.&n=
bsp; But if the number 
                            of bytes are the same, =
it tends to indicate the 
                            files are likely the =
same, but you still need a low 
                            level file comp=
arison to be sure.<br><br>My method 
                            is to comp=
are the files using the CMP command in 
                            unix.&n=
bsp; There are many programs to compare 
                            files,=
 but you have to be careful not to use one 
                            tha=
t does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison 
                           =
 meant for text files), since text files can be 
                          =
  different at a low level, but look essential the 
                       =
     same in an editor (because of the way spaces and 
                    =
        tabs and new lines work between editors and 
                      =
      platforms).<br><br>But anyway, the way to compare is 
               =
             with a program that can compare binary files, not 
           =
                 text files.<br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April

       <tr>
                                <td valign=3D"top">A file's con=
tent, it's integrity, 
                                is simply the bytes =
(and their bits) in the 
                                file.  If the=
 file's content integrity is 
                                changed, that=
 is, by definition, changing the 
                                bytes.&nb=
sp; If the bytes in there are not 
                                changed,=
 then that integrity has not 
                                changed.<br><=
br>It is possible to mess with 
                                other thing=
s about a file (like its name, its 
                                suffix,=
 or its ownership) but this does not 
                                effec=
t the contents, and so would not affect 
                                th=
at integrity, or the sound of the file 
                                (as=
suming you could read it at all after 
                                chan=
ging the ownership, or the suffix, 
                                etc).<b=
r><br>When you do your tests, if you 
                                canno=
t do a bit level comparison, I would 
                                recom=
mend at least checking the file 
                                sizes.&nbs=
p; If they are identical, there is a 
                                very =
high probability that the content has not 
                                =
changed.<br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun,
